message.content: This question requires knowledge about the concept of friction. Friction is the force that opposes motion when two surfaces rub against each other. Option (B) is the correct answer because rubbing knees involves two surfaces coming into contact and experiencing friction. Option (A) is incorrect because breathing does not involve two surfaces rubbing against each other. Option (C) is incorrect because running involves the motion of the body, but not necessarily two surfaces rubbing against each other. Option (D) is incorrect because rainbows are a natural phenomenon caused by the refraction and reflection of light, not friction.

This question requires basic knowledge about the concept of friction. Friction is a force that acts between two surfaces in contact with each other and opposes their motion. Option (B) is correct because rubbing your knees together creates friction between them. Option (A) is incorrect because breathing does not involve surfaces in contact. Option (C) is incorrect because running involves more than just friction, such as propulsion from muscles. Option (D) is incorrect because rainbows are not related to friction at all.

This question tests the understanding of what friction is and how it occurs. Friction is the force that resists the relative motion between two surfaces in contact with each other. Rubbing knees is an example of two surfaces (knees) coming into contact and experiencing friction. Option (A) is incorrect because breathing is not related to friction. Option (C) is related to motion but not specifically to friction. Option (D) is unrelated as rainbows are a visual phenomenon caused by light refraction, not friction.
